Message.Title: Barrons Today--to mid 20's?
Message.Msg: Yahoo! (YHOO): The fund started buying stock before activist investor Dan Loeb of Third Point took aim at the company. Schoenfeld says he's extremely happy with the new board, and thinks new CEO Marissa Mayer will "try to monetize some of their investments. We think if executed properly the stock should be trading in the low to mid 20s," up from $15.95 last week.

Message.Title: Barrons also-streaming live music-cool
Message.Msg: So Weir, 64, and some business partners have opened a high-end music studio and teamed up with Yahoo! to stream musical performances over the Internet. Yahoo! runs ads in the videos and splits revenue 50/50 with Weir's San Raphael, Calif.-based studio, known as the Tamalpais Research Institute. TRI in turn splits its revenue 50/50 with the musical acts.

Message.Title: IF Marissa can develop mobile ad revenue stream
Message.Msg: when users are transitioning to their cell phone and tablets, Yahoo will become that 100 Billion company it used to be in 2001. Then Marissa deserves to be CEO. And it explains why Levinsohn was passed over for the CEO job.

Topic.Title: Sold Mine and Going Short On This

Message.Msg: Her career bio is no doubt impressive (at least on paper) for a tricenarian; I believe she’s only 39. But to turn YHOO into a mega moolah-generating machine that would in turn boost its stock price significantly, that, would be a very tall order indeed. Just look at the case of Meg Whitman. One would be hard put to match her biz credentials. Hired by HPQ last September to catapult the company forward, she has to date taken its stock for an odious bath, presently a haircut of roughly 18% since her inception. Short of a buyout, some superhuman efforts here are needed to move Yahoo’s current stagnating share price out of the doldrums. In fact, on a recent Charlie Rose’s show, Bill Gates still expressed interest in such a move to boost its internet search engine biz. But Steve Ballmer now calls the shots and apparently has other ideas, otherwise he would have finalized such a deal eons ago. So, if one doesn’t mind having one’s funds stuck in the mud for a considerable lapse of time, rather than putting them to work more productively in this volatile period, then, it’s quite alright to dock them here for relative safety for the foreseeable moons ahead. Best to you.
